results.title: Arafat: Behind the myth
results.creator_credit: Anthony Geffen, BBC Enterprises and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: An in-depth analysis of the character and work of legendary Palestinian Liberation Organisation leader, Yasir Arafat. A look at the man behind the media facade.

results.title: Arachnida
results.brief_description: Part one deals with the study of the external features of spiders, and their habits including different methods of web-building and catching food. Types of spiders include: garden spider, water spider, and raft spider. Coition and the spinning of cocoons to protect eggs is also shown. The second part of the film supplements the above material, showing biological relatives of these spiders, including the primitive sea scorpions, found only as fossils, the aquatic king crab, land crabs, carnivorous harvestmen, and the ararina, including the cheesemite, red spiders, sheep tick, and the so-called sea spiders. Commentary by Carleton Hobbs, photography by Charles D. Head and F. Percy Smith. No other credits available. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Arabian Nights
results.creator_credit: Dyson Lovell, Golden Horn Films, Hallmark Entertainment and Steve Barron
results.brief_description: A spellbinding set of stories brought to life by an all-star cast, based on Sir Richard Burton’s translation of “The Thousand and One Nights”. Schahriar, Sultan of Bagdad, must remarry before the next full moon, else his brother Schahzenan, will inherit the kingdom. Tormented with recurrent images of the assassination attempt made by his first wife and his treacherous brother, Schahriar decides that he will wed a woman from the harem - then have her executed the next morning to prevent another betrayal. The petrified concubines ask Scheherezade, the beautiful daughter of the Sultan’s Grand Vizier, Jafar, for help. Scheherezade, having always loved Schahriah, agrees to marry him, determined to save him from the madness that threatens to consume him and tear the kingdom apart. On her wedding night, Scheherezade begins to regale her husband with a series of magical tales, always breaking off at dawn and leaving him so intrigued that he postpones her execution. However, as Schahriar slowly begins to yield to his wife’s captivating stories and kind heart, his brother, desperate to rule the kingdom and get revenge, is assembling an army to storm the palace. Scheherezade’s stories include Ali Baba and the Forty Thieves, Bac Bac the Hunchback, and Aladdin and the Genie of the Lamp. Originally filmed as a two-part mini-series, “Arabian nights” is a captivating production, featuring ornate costuming, opulent set design, and a host of suitably exotic locations. Cast includes Mili Avital, Dougray Scott, Alan Bates, Jason Scott Lee, and John Legiuzamo, with additional appearances by Rufus Sewell, Alexei Sayle, Tcheky Karyo, and Vanessa Mae.

results.title: Arabian children
results.creator_credit: Donald G. Hoffman and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: The life of a family living on a farm in Saahab in TransJordan. Describes the events of a typical day and shows the children minding sheep, working in the fields and in the house, going to school and visiting a nearby village. It also emphasises the importance of water and the camel to their way of life.

results.title: Arab traders of the Persian Gulf
results.creator_credit: Peggie Broadhead and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People of Many Lands”.
A journey across the barren desert areas of the Gulf of Arabia with Arab traders. These are nomadic people living in primitive conditions. The film is one of a series which deals with a wide range of people, some of whom have retained primitive ways of life and have little contact with the outside world.

results.title: Aquatic wizards
results.brief_description: A short 50s newsreel with a light-hearted commentary, filmed at Cyprus Gardens in Florida, featuring male and female bathing beauties demonstrating a selection of water skiing styles. Begins with groups of young boys and girls learning to ski, followed by examples of the different types of skis. The films proceeds to adult skiers such as champion Alfredo Medoza (also referred to as the Mexican Jumping Bean) demonstrating a variety of jumps. Also features champion and innovative skier Willa McGuire performing the technique she originated known as swivel skiing, combining ballet with water skiing.

results.title: Aquarium
results.brief_description: Brilliantly photographed non-narrated tableau of unusual underwater creatures including fish that walk on their ‘hands’, sea horses and octopus. Explores the feeding habits and methods of locomotion of these marine life forms. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Apt 3 (K)
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: Wistful harmonica music drifting from an unknown apartment leads Sam and his little brother Ben on a search for its origin. Their discovery provides them with an insight beyond vision and a sense of beauty in the midst of gloom. Subtle tones of greys, greens and purples and the accompanying harmonica score enhance this poignant film. Based on the book by Ezra Jack Keats. Narrated by Charles Turner, music by Sugar Blue.

results.title: Approaching poetry in English literature
results.creator_credit: Daryl Wayland, Television Production Unit, Box Hill College of TAFE and David Zweck
results.brief_description: Dr Ray Misson of Melbourne College of Advanced Education seeks to demystify poetry by providing a guide for students to help their approach to this area of literature. In a practical commonsense manner, he uses poems by Donne, Browning, Marvell and Coleridge as examples.
